head.headtext: Expressions of regret, mistake, error, sympathy, or apology

para.paratext: Expressions of sympathy or benevolence are not admissions of liability for a tort. In Dougherty v. Woodward,[1] the Georgia Court of Appeals held that a father did not admit liability for his son's negligence by telling the decedent's mother that “he would do the right thing by her.”

Following the principle of Dougherty, the court in Gray v. Delta Air Lines, Inc.[2] upheld the lower court's decision to strike the allegation that the defendant had paid plaintiff's hospital bill from plaintiff's complaint.

Again, in Steverson v. Eason,[3] the court upheld the lower court's refusal to give an instruction on an admission by the defendant based upon defendant's statement to the decedent's wife that he felt responsible for her husband's death and that he would do whatever he could for her.

Inasmuch, “an admission of liability has efficacy only if there is liability.”[4] If there is none, then expressions of regret, mistake, error, sympathy, or apology by an alleged tortfeasor are considered to be mere expressions of sympathy, benevolence, or an acceptance of moral responsibility, not liability.[5]

Through O.C.G.A. § 24-4-416, the Georgia General Assembly codified this rule for any expressions of regret, mistake, error, sympathy, or apology made by a health-care provider to a patient or his family. The statute provides:

(a) As used in this Code section, the term “health care provider” means any person licensed under Chapter 9, 10A, 11, 11A, 26, 28, 30, 33, 34, 35, 39, or 44 of Title 43 or any hospital, nursing home, home health agency, institution, or medical facility licensed or defined under Chapter 7 of Title 31. The term shall also include any corporation, professional corporation, partnership, limited liability company, limited liability partnership, authority, or other entity composed of such health care providers.

(b) In any claim or civil proceeding brought by or on behalf of a patient allegedly experiencing an unanticipated outcome of medical care, any and all statements, affirmations, gestures, activities, or conduct expressing regret, apology, sympathy, commiseration, condolence, compassion, mistake, error, or a general sense of benevolence which is made by a health care provider or an employee or agent of a health care provider to the patient, a relative of the patient, or a representative of the patient and which relates to the unanticipated outcome shall be inadmissible as evidence and shall not constitute an admission of liability or an admission against interest.

Applying the former version of this statute, the Georgia Court of Appeals upheld the exclusion of evidence that a physician was “white as his jacket” and “quite upset” after surgery and that the physician stated that “[t]his was my fault” to the patient.[6]
Dougherty v. Woodward, 21 Ga. App. 427, 430, 94 S.E. 636 (1917).
Gray v. Delta Air Lines, Inc., 127 Ga. App. 45, 192 S.E.2d 521 (1972).
Steverson v. Eason, 194 Ga. App. 273, 390 S.E.2d 424 (1990).
Widner v. Brookins, Inc., 236 Ga. App. 563, 565, 512 S.E.2d 405 (1999).
See Trulove v. Jones, 271 Ga. App. 681, 610 S.E.2d 649 (2005) (citing Widner v. Brookins, Inc., 236 Ga. App. 563, 512 S.E.2d 405 (1999)).
See also Steverson v. Eason, 194 Ga. App. 273, 273–274, 390 S.E.2d 424 (1990) (statement by defendant that he felt responsible for plaintiff's husband's death was not an admission of liability).
Airasian v. Shaak, 289 Ga. App. 540, 540, 657 S.E.2d 600 (2008).
